comments.body: could / should we use pandas.core.dtypes.cast.find_common_type here instead? (or move this logic there)

Possibly...

At a glance it looks like `pandas.core.dtypes.casts.find_common_type` is more careful with

* datetime
* timedelta
* bool and other

Will look into it.
ok,, yeah would be nice to simplify this
this should be in the if/elif below
sort of dumb, but no blank lines before/after

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +385,389 @@        elif is_datetime64tz_dtype(dtype):
            upcast_cls = "datetimetz"

        elif is_extension_array_dtype(dtype):
            upcast_cls = "extension"

comments.body: This change is actually not equivalent. We have both ExtensionBlock as other Block types that are subclasses from ExtensionBlock.

@jorisvandenbossche Thanks, in the first iteration of the PR, I actually retained the exact type check and opted for a `#  noqa`.  Should this be a new issue?  We could also require this behavior in a test.

I was actually just looking at this. In the meantime it also seems that the location where this `_is_uniform_join_units` is used isn't that strict anymore about the exact block types (due to https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/33486), so it should be fine as is.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +444,448 @@    return (
        # all blocks need to have the same type
        all(isinstance(ju.block, type(join_units[0].block)) for ju in join_units)
        and  # noqa
        # no blocks that would get missing values (can lead to type upcasts)
